title: 105_hr3568
content: The Act titled "Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998" revises limits on mental health benefits. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998 expand coverage under ERISA for group health plans and insurance to include mental health benefits without imposing treatment limitations or financial requirements if not imposed on medical and surgical benefits in comparable settings. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998 require equal coverage for mental health benefits compared to medical and surgical benefits in group health plans, without imposing treatment limitations or financial requirements. The section also allows for separate reimbursement rates and benefit management strategies. It also allows for separate reimbursement rates and benefit management strategies. Amendments include eliminating cost exemptions and sunset provisions. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998 require equal coverage for mental health benefits in group health plans by eliminating cost exemptions and sunset provisions. Amendments also expand coverage to include treatment limitations and financial requirements. Group health plans can manage benefits through various mechanisms such as pre-admission screening and prior authorization of services. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998 define treatment limits and financial requirements for group health plans, eliminating cost exemptions and the sunset provision. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998 eliminate sunset provision and certain cost exemptions for group health plans. Amendments include striking subsections and making clerical changes to the Internal Revenue Code and Public Health Service Act. SEC. 2752. PARITY IN THE APPLICATION OF LIMITS TO MENTAL HEALTH BENEFITS. The provisions of section 2705 apply to health insurance coverage in the individual market as they do in connection with a group health plan. Effective dates for group health plans begin on or after July 1, 1999. The amendments made by subsections (a), (b), and (c) shall not apply to plan years beginning before the later of the date on which the last collective bargaining agreements relating to the plan terminates or July 1, 1999. Any plan amendment made pursuant to a collective bargaining agreement solely to conform to the agreement is exempt. The amendment made by subsection (d) applies to individual health insurance coverage in the market from July 1, 1999 onwards. Coordination in implementation is effective upon enactment of the Act, amending section 104(1) of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996. Effective on the date of enactment, section 104(1) of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 is amended to coordinate with parts of other acts and codes. SEC. 3. PARITY IN THE APPLICATION OF LIMITS TO SUBSTANCE ABUSE AND CHEMICAL DEPENDENCY BENEFITS. This section amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 to ensure that limits on benefits for substance abuse and chemical dependency treatment are applied in the same manner as mental health benefits. Sec. 713 amends the Public Health Service Act and the Internal Revenue Code to ensure parity in the application of limits to substance abuse and chemical dependency benefits. Sec. 9813 ensures parity in the application of limits to substance abuse and chemical dependency benefits under the Public Health Service Act. "SEC. 2753 ensures parity in the application of limits to mental health benefits." The provisions of section 2752 apply to substance abuse and chemical dependency treatment benefits in the same way as mental health benefits. Effective dates for group health plans begin on or after July 1, 1999, with exceptions for plans under collective bargaining agreements. Employers who ratified agreements before the enactment of this Act are exempt from certain plan amendments until the later of the termination of collective bargaining agreements or July 1, 1999. Plan amendments made to comply with new requirements will not be considered terminations. The collective bargaining agreement relating to the plan can be amended to conform to new requirements without being considered a termination. The amendment regarding individual health insurance coverage applies to coverage in the individual market on or after July 1, 1999.
